body:
This release includes many bug fixes, improvements to system call coverage, and incremental performance improvements. Plus:
* ARM Aarch64 support is now production quality (features implemented and tests pass), with [some caveats](https://github.com/rr-debugger/rr/issues/3234). Recent iterations of Cortex and Neoverse (AWS Graviton) chips are supported, as is Apple M1 (when running Linux on bare metal M1). `LDREX`/`STREX` are not supported; userspace code must use Large System Extensions atomics only. Thanks to Yichao Yu and Keno Fischer for this work! We don't have prebuilt ARM packages yet.
* Recording applications that use `RDTSC` heavily should be much faster than in previous versions of rr.
* The `rseq` system call is now supported (via emulation).
As usual there are many bug fixes, improvements to system call coverage, and incremental performance improvements. Thanks to all our contributors.

As usual there are many bug fixes, improvements to system call coverage, and incremental performance improvements. Thanks to all our contributors.

AMD Zen CPUs are now [supported](https://github.com/mozilla/rr/wiki/Zen), with some caveats. Special thanks to the people who [reverse-engineered](https://github.com/mozilla/rr/issues/2034) Zen details to enable this.

There is experimental support for ARM AArch64 platforms that avoid the `STREX` instruction.

`rr record` has a new option `--nested=detach` which lets nested rr recordings run "detached" to create a separate recording.

This is primarily a maintenance release. There are many bug fixes, improvements to system call coverage, and incremental performance improvements. Thanks to all our contributors.

The `rr sources`, `rr buildid` and `rr traceinfo` commands have been added to make it easier for external tools to work with rr traces. `rr ls` has been added to improve management of traces.

rr no longer depends on Python 2. Python 3 is required.

Maintenance update to handle issues arising from Ubuntu 18.04 and Fedora 28.
Improvements to chaos mode.
Improvements to trace portability: https://robert.ocallahan.org/2018/04/cpuid-features-xsave-and-rr-trace.html
Various bug fixes.

gdb `info proc map` supported.
Maintenance update to handle issues arising from Ubuntu 17.10 and Fedora 27.
Various bugs fixed.
No 32-bit release packages included because my 32-bit VM broke. Let's see if anyone complains.

Introduction of Cap'n Proto to [stabilize the recording format](http://robert.ocallahan.org/2017/08/stabilizing-rr-trace-format.html). Recordings created in this rr release should be replayable in any future rr release.
New [`rr pack`](http://robert.ocallahan.org/2017/06/new-rr-pack-command.html) command makes recordings self-contained.
Recordings can be made on one machine and replayed on a different machine by [trapping CPUID instructions](http://robert.ocallahan.org/2017/09/rr-trace-portability.html) when supported on the replay machine.
[Brotli compression](http://robert.ocallahan.org/2017/07/selecting-compression-algorithm-for-rr.html) for smaller traces and lower recording overhead.
`rr replay` command line argument `--` can be followed by any number of arguments to be passed to the debugger.
`rr` now chooses `replay` as the default subcommand if the first argument is a directory.  
Performance improvements.
Syscall support expanded.
Many bugs fixed.

Work around [a Linux kernel bug](https://lkml.org/lkml/2017/1/5/13) induced by DirtyCOW fix.
Support for [Hardware Lock Elision](http://robert.ocallahan.org/2016/11/handling-hardware-lock-elision-in-rr.html), with detection of [a KVM PMU virtualization](http://marc.info/?l=kvm&m=148592204503332&w=2) bug that breaks HLE support.
Make syscall-buffering use an alternate stack (makes Go programs work).
Syscall support expanded (especially `ptrace` subcalls).
Support for Knights Landing and Kaby Lake CPUs.
Many bugs fixed.
Great thanks to Keno Fischer for much of this work!

Compile releases with `CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release` for improved performance.
Support for record and replay of `chromium-browser` and `google-chrome` via various bug fixes: notably, syncing syscall writes to mmapped files, and handling tasks forked with invalid TLS areas.
Many improvements to make signal-state tracking match the kernel more accurately.
Support for Linux 4.8 kernels (in particular, `PTRACE_SYSCALL` notifications being delivered before `seccomp` notifications instead of after).
General recording overhead improvements (thanks to Keno Fischer).
Support for accessing thread-local variables while debugging (thanks to Tom Tromey).
Syscall support expanded.
Many bugs fixed.

Debugging support for AVX (YMM) registers.
Optimizations for tracees doing heavy I/O, when on btrfs.
Support for `dconf`'s shared memory.
Much better support for `vfork`.
Support for tracees calling `setuid()` (when rr is running as root).
Support for tracees compiled with AddressSanitizer.
Support for optimized release builds: `-DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release` (thanks to Keno Fischer).
Some internal cleanup (thanks to Keno Fischer).
Syscall support expanded.
Many bugs fixed, including support for Ubuntu 16.04, Fedora 24 and latest grsecurity kernels (thanks to Brad Spengler).

Chaos mode added to catch hard-to-reproduce bugs.
Added support for using kernel ftrace while debugging rr itself.
Rework logging code so that logging can be turned on via RR_LOG environment variable or dynamically.
Reworked robust-futex handling.
Work around RDRAND usage in libstdc++3.
Syscall support expanded.
Many bugs fixed, particularly related to Ubuntu 14.04 and 15.10.

Major improvements in replay performance by avoiding traps to rr during syscallbuf replay.
Intel Skylake supported.
Worked around kernel bug causing uninterruptible tracee processes.
Emulate MAP_GROWSDOWN during recording and replay so we never have real auto-growing mappings.
Implement backend for gdb `find` command.
Various bugs fixed.
Minor update fixing bugs and supporting a few more system calls.

Minor update fixing build issues, handle a few more system calls, and fix some minor bugs.

Also adds `rr replay -d <debugger>` to run an arbitrary gdb front-end instead of just gdb.

This is the first stable release supporting reverse execution in gdb.

This release contains many architectural improvements, performance improvements, stability fixes, and improved hardware, kernel and application compatibility.
